Salty is the first significant Hollywood film to be funded in this way.

BE

Two plausible
outcomes for Sky if it is disallowed could be: (i) Sky’s MVNO offer would stay
with O2, whose network spend lags peers and where Telefonica is a seller. (ii)
Sky could conceivably consider buying O2. If Sky ( ex-synergies) paid, say £9bn
(our hypothetical mid-point value, discussed inside) against Three’s proposed
£10.25bn ( with synergies), that would be 6.4x EBITDA and could produce
incremental equity FCF of as much as £465m, equivalent to 45% of Sky’s FY17
FCF. Such a deal would be financially stretching (initial net debt/ equity of 5.5x
ex any equity raise, asset sales). This may be too bold for Sky, and we note that
it has not expressed any such plans.

Greg Johnson

PM

Q1 update – Guidance for FY EBIT of £260-£280m post the recent shock warning was reiterated suggesting trading has stabilised in recent weeks. Overall, trading for 17 weeks to 26th April paints a pretty disappointing backdrop, with group NGR down 3%, with online down 11%, Australia down 22%, Retail ahead by 2% and US ahead 46%.

In online we were disappointed to see UK amounts wagered falling by 2% and gaming net revenues down 5% suggesting market share losses. In Australia, amounts wagered were ahead by 10%, offset by poor horseracing results, but remains where we would hope given the repositioning. In retail, it was encouraging to see gaming machine income ahead by 9% in recent weeks since rolling over from last April’s “£50 Journey”.

Although forecasts will likely remain unchanged post today’s update the trading position remains sluggish. Although we see support from a cash flow perspective, free cash flow yield of 7%, we see little to get encouraged about until the group starts to generate material growth in NGR in the UK and Australian markets. Hold.

Online net revenue was -11% yoy in the period. Sportsbook revenue was -17% yoy while
gaming was -4% yoy. Sportsbook amounts wagered were -2% yoy, with core markets +1%
and non-core -13%. In core markets, UK amounts wagered were -2%, with Spain and Italy
growing by double digits. The gross win margin, impacted by Cheltenham and European
football results, fell 90bps to 6.3%. UK gaming net revenue was -5%, with Vegas growing
and Casino declining. The statement notes that trends on self-exclusions and time-outs,
highlighted in March, remain unchanged. Crispin Nieboer has been appointed Managing
Director of Online, having been interim head since January.

Overall, there are no major surprises in this morning’s release. The company has
re-iterated FY operating profit guidance given on March 23rd of £260-280m (we
are at the bottom of this range at £261m). There are some positives to be taken
from this update including (i) a resilient retail performance (machines); (ii) a
better performance in Australia, albeit from a low base; and (iii) continued strong
growth in the US. The valuation is not overly stretched at current levels. However,
we retain our cautious view given that significant work is needed to turn around its
online business, which will take time (the KPIs highlighted in online look bad in
comparison to what peers have reported).

BE

PM

Following Barratt's 3Q16 trading update, we maintain our Neutral rating and 568p TP and make no changes to earnings
forecasts. Barratt reported positive trading conditions in the 19 weeks from 1st January 2016 and maintain a confident
outlook for the remainder of the year and into FY17.
 Positive 3Q16 trading results - strong demand levels in the period enabled Barratt to increase its total forward sales
position, as of 8th May 2016, +10% YoY to £2.84bn. Group private sales rates increased to 0.75 net private reservations
per active outlet per week (vs. 0.74 in 3Q14/15).
 Land approvals increased - of particular note in the statement was the Group's increased guidance on land approvals for
FY16. Management now expect to approve between 21,000-23,000 plots in FY16. This represents a strong increase from
the previous guidance of 18,000 plots and is a reflection of the continued attractive conditions of the land market being
experienced in the wider regional markets throughout the UK.

11:30 am
PM

London market divided - activity in London appears strong below the £600k house price threshold due to the introduction of
the London Help to Buy scheme. Barratt state that the share of private reservations using the scheme in the period
increased to 38% (from 25% 2015). However, whilst management reiterate their focus on land opportunities in zones 3-6,
they remain relatively more cautious on inner London where they state they "had not been able to secure opportunities in
zones 1 and 2, given our minimum hurdle rates".
 Net cash guidance increased - reflecting the timing of certain land payments falling into FY16/17, guidance for FY16 net
cash position has been increased to £300-350m (from c.£250m previous guidance).
 CS view - overall a solid 3Q16 trading update from Barratt, with the improved forward sales position reflecting the ongoing
positive conditions in the wider UK housing market. However, trading on 1.6x our 2016 (calendarised) P/TNAV, we believe
the Group remains fairly valued. Neutral rating maintained.

PM

Fairly valued

11:32 am
BE

Inter-generational wealth transfer – more commonly referred to as the ‘bank of mum and dad’, this source of lending was characterised last week as being the equivalent of a top 10 mortgage lender. Some £5bn is estimated to have been invested in 2015, but unlike a mortgage, these funds were largely not for repayment nor did they incur (in the main) any interest.

Long-dated mortgages – the CML showed that close to 60% of first time buyers now have mortgages with maturities longer than 25 years; this is up from 40% in 2009. This is a reasonably understandable development as its enables borrowers to achieve a ‘low start’ mortgage as they start out in home ownership. Of some greater concern is the rise in the percentage of home movers and re-mortgagors using long-dated loans. Movers have increased from around 16% to 36% long-dated since 2009 and re-mortgagors from 6% to 20% (Figure 7).

100% mortgages – there have a been a handful 100% mortgages available for some time, mainly from the challenger banks, but last week Barclays entered the fray. While still requiring a parental guarantee and 10% of the loan pledged as a surety, the 5% hard deposit previously required is gone and the surety is only required for three years. So, after 3 years it become a pure 100% mortgage. The loan costs just 2.99% fixed and 5.5x salary can borrowed. This is low cost, high ratio lending that could signal a growing appetite for riskier mortgage lending: this has echoes of pre-crisis lending, in our view.

Mortgages for 85 year olds – Nationwide has announced that borrowers may now run a mortgage until the age of 85; previously the latest was 75. The intention, we surmise, is to help re-mortgaging among older borrowers, but the risk is of an alternative use with house movers extending their purchasing power or the ability to lower monthly payments materially and, to some extent, begin to use one’s house as a cash machine: more echoes of the pre-crisis climate. It is notable that the average UK life expectancy today is just 81.5 years (Source: World Bank).

BE

Unhelpful in the longer term
While many of the methods used to help potential buyers into the housing market do bring the initial benefit of the ‘leg–up’ or ‘helping hand’, in the longer term we see such moves being unhelpful as, like other artificial aids in the housing market, they create only an illusion of affordability. Parental contributions are unlikely to be available for a house purchase beyond the first step, 100% mortgage holders are likely to have LTV problems when trying to move up the market, long-dated mortgages limit the ability to build equity and taking a very long dated mortgage earlier in life limits flexibility in later life or when problems arise. Overriding all of this is our view that, in different ways, all such shifts in house funding and purchase risk being inflationary.

BE

The mechanisms increasingly being employed by lenders are, in our view, potentially inflationary. While the intention might be, superficially at least, to maintain affordability, we see instead inflationary drivers arising from such policies.

Buying power extension – granting a 35 year mortgage lowers the monthly service cost by 15-20% (depending on the interest rate) versus a 25 year loan. The intention is to make an equivalent purchase more affordable, but the lower cost can also be used to drive up buying power. As long as the LTI ratio does rise too far, a buyer can choose to purchase a more expensive house or, and more dangerously, be tempted to pay more for the same house, a situation potentially quite common in today’s market where there is a large surfeit of buyers. This is similar to the way that interest-only mortgages caused inflationary pressure before the financial crisis.

Buyer pool enlargement – the likes of 100% loans and very long-dated mortgage loans not only reduce the funding load of an individual loan or extend the buyer power of the individual, they also materially enlarge the potential pool of buyers who can enter the market. These actions push the average salary (individual or household) needed to be able to consider buying a house back along the wage distribution curve and would raise the potential number of buyers exponentially (Figures 4 & 5). As creating new buyers has no impact on the net size of housing stock, we believe that there is a major inflationary risk attached. Historically there has been a strong correlation between higher housing demand (reflected in mortgage approvals) and house price inflation (Figure 8).

Classic goal post movement – allowing people to borrow more or borrow for longer is not a major problem per se, but there is a problem if those policies are arrived at by a major movement of the goal posts. In the UK housing market there is a long and often painful history related to a moving of the goal posts, usually tax-related, and there is ample evidence that rising house price inflation is typically a result.

Taking all of the likely and potential consequences of the recent developments in mortgage lending, one could easily see that the Bank of England might be considering that some form of intervention is needed. Lending policy seems to be loosening fairly rapidly with policy changes looking to compensate, in our view, for the deceleration in the fall in mortgage rates to deflect falling affordability. House prices are now rising faster than mortgage rates are falling making mortgage servicing more expensive. As figure 3 shows, mortgage servicing costs have increased very little in recent years despite the steep rise in average prices as mortgage rates have dropped. However, there has been a rising trend in mortgage servicing costs for almost the last year.

The last major changes to lending rules were made back in 2014 with the more rigorous affordability tests (including the +300bips stress test) that were introduced as part of the MMR that April and the 15% limit on 4.5x LTIs that was put in place that August. There are various forms that new restrictions could take: absolute stress test interest rates rather than +300bips as now; more restrictive LTI caps; limits of market share of very long-dated mortgages; imposing restrictions on 100% LTV loans.

BE

Summary: Plus500 is a retail financial trading platform listed on AIM. It
allows end-customers to trade contracts-for-difference (CFDs) on a wide
range of underlying financial securities, such as stocks, options, indices, FX
and commodities. It ultimately derives revenue from dealing spreads and
overnight premiums on customer positions. From $56m revenue in 2012,
the firm has grown rapidly to $276m in 2015, with strong EBITDA margins.
However, the firm ran into a series of regulatory headwinds during this
period which culminated in a suspension of client onboarding in 2015. We
are well aware that the firm has past failings with regards to meeting
regulatory criteria in certain end-markets. However, we also believe it has
significantly improved its regulatory compliance and that customer
onboarding began again at the start of 2016. We note its discount to listed
peers, such as IG Group, is material and initiate with a Buy rating.
● Historical growth ahead of market: Since its IPO in 2013, Plus500 has
grown customer numbers and revenues much faster than the overall
market for retail FX, CFD and spread betting. While management’s current
focus is on rebuilding regulatory credibility, we note that industry
forecasts are suggesting the market could grow, with an 8-9% CAGR 2014-
18 as geographic diversification, product breadth and accessibility continue
to increase.
● Marketing success: Plus500 grows through having more clients trading in
larger volumes more frequently. As a result, its development of a strong
marketing model has been key to driving the historical levels of revenue
growth. Customer numbers have increased from 58,300 in 2012 to 136,500
by the end of 2015, and average revenue per customer has moved from
$962 in 2012 to $2,020 in 2015.
● Strong cash conversion: In addition to the high growth and high margins,
cash requirements in the business are low. As such, as of FY 2015 results,
Plus500 has paid out $230m in dividends since its IPO versus an initial
market cap of c$200m. With very limited capex and working capital
requirements, we would expect the strong cash conversion and high
shareholder payouts to continue.
● Regulatory overhang: In May 2015, Plus500 entered “voluntary
requirement” restrictions under the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)
legislation while it improved anti-money laundering procedures in its UK
subsidiary. The firm temporarily suspended new trading by existing
customers as well as the onboarding of new clients. We believe Plus500
has made significant improvements in regulatory compliance over the past
year, but further regulatory intervention remains a risk.

BE

BE

PM

March industrial production printed marginally weaker than our below-consensus expectation, registering growth of 0.3% m/m. The main driver behind positive growth was electricity & gas which printed 3.3% m/m (+0.3pp contrib.). Manufacturing, too, contributed positively, albeit more modestly (0.1% m/m, +0.1pp contrib.); growth in manufacturing was driven by transport equipment (+0.2pp contrib.), machinery (+0.1pp contrib.) and metals (+0.1pp contrib.), although this was partially offset by food & beverages (-0.2pp contrib.). Meanwhile, water & waste management was muted (0.2% m/m, 0.0pp contrib.) and mining & quarrying marginally detracted (-0.4% m/m, -0.1pp contrib.).

PM

Quarterly growth of industrial production, meanwhile, remains contractionary, having declined by -0.4% q/q in Q1 16 after -0.4% q/q in Q4 15. The Q1 16 contraction was driven by both manufacturing (-0.5% q/q, -0.3pp contrib.), with weakness registered in broadly all subcomponents, and mining & quarrying (-2.3% q/q, -0.3pp contrib.). The weakness in manufacturing and mining & quarrying, however, was partially offset by water & waste management (2.3% q/q, +0.2pp contrib.). Meanwhile, electricity & gas output was muted over the quarter (0.0% q/q and 0.0pp contrib.).

11:44 am
PM

With weakness registered across both manufacturing and volatile components, this supports our view that UK industrial production remains a cause for concern. We believe this is driven by a structural lack of competitiveness, itself magnified by a strong currency, which although has depreciated since mid-November 2015, is still historically strong, and government policies (fiscal consolidation, the apprenticeship levy as well as the introduction of the national living wage). Equally, we believe that rising EU referendum uncertainty is weighing on firms’ ability to export, with surveys (PMI, VBI, EEF, etc.) suggesting a decline in new orders on the back of said EU referendum risk. Looking forward, April surveys on manufacturing output (PMI, CBI, etc.) suggest that the deterioration is likely to continue, which is supported by the EEF Q1 16 Outlook Report (released 9 March 2016; the EEF is the manufacturer’s representative body) in which the EEF revised down its manufacturing output growth forecast for 2016; at the end of 2015, it forecasted 0.8% growth in output for 2016 whereas it is now forecast at 0.6%. A continued contraction of industrial production into Q2 16 would support our view that economic growth is to slow to flat in Q2 16 after printing an estimated 0.4% q/q in Q1 16.

PM

PM

(NEX LN) Strong start to the year, on target to hit FY profit, FCF and leverage targets. Revenue growth at all divisions, with underlying group revenue growth of 4%. UK Bus commercial revenue growth 3%, flat passenger volumes. UK Coach 4% underlying revenue growth, 6% volume growth, despite a notable reduction in volumes after the Brussels attacks. Forward bookings indicate a recovery from a weak April. UK Rail: 7% LFL volume growth at c2c, agreed with DfT to bring forward the introduction of new trains by three years. Spain: 5% volume growth, 3% revenue growth, supported by revenue management, new contract wins and an acquisition. Morocco 11% volume growth. North American School Bus: very high retention rate at 96%, average price increase of 5% on renewed business. Transit: continued growth. German Rail: mobilisation successful, trading in line, still on course to breakeven this year. Overall, encouraging and suggesting that trading at National Express is stronger than at any of the other public transport operators. Positive read across to FirstGroup from the school bus contract pricing comments.

here's Jefferies.

BE

We tend to find it difficult to fully reconcile National Express’s trading updates
to our forecasts given their typical focus on more detailed data points – but the
positive tone of today's IMS update is clear. At the headline level: “The Group
has made a strong start to the year”…and…”remains on target to deliver its
profit expectation and free cash flow and leverage targets for the year.”
At the headline level: Four months into the financial year, all divisions are reported to
have increased revenue and, despite absorbing higher bid costs, group PBT is up YoY in
constant currency (we expect FX benefits to build on that this year).
Across the disclosed data points, we find interesting (1) the best start of the year “ever”
for School Bus in North America due to less weather disruption, though we'd therefore
expect fewer catch-up days later in the year to part unwind the current benefit. Also notable
is the 96% retention rate in the bid season so far, securing 5% average rate increase. (2) In
Spain, revenue growth of +3% looks as we expected. (3) Passenger volumes in UK coach
are up 6% despite a weak April following the Brussels terrorist atrocities in late March
(improvements in advanced bookings now being seen). (4) 3% commercial revenue growth
in UK Bus compares with 2% that we look for across the full year. (5) 7% growth in passenger
journeys reported on c2c (we believe dragging passengers away from the District Line post
December's timetable changes) and agreement to bring 24 new carriages into service this
year, three years early, at no net cost to the group. (6) The successful mobilisation of German
Rail operations is noted – repeats steer for breakeven this year. (7) Resolution on the awarded
but disputed Nuremburg and Porto contracts is now not expected before 2H.

BE

Our view: As detailed in our recent note Wind Assisted for FY16 and Beyond, we view National
Express as offering a base of solid prospects with overlay of bidding activity that has the
potential to build on that, particularly East Anglia to be awarded in July. This update serves
to reaffirm our view.
Valuation: On an ex-rail basis, we believe National Express trades on 10.9x 12-month
forward EV/EBIT vs FGP at 8.9x, GOG at 12.2x and SGC at 12.4x.
